analytic.title: Fast Linearized Coronagraph Optimizer (FALCO) IV. Coronagraph design survey for obstructed and segmented apertures

abstract.p: Coronagraph instruments on future space telescopes will enable the direct detection and characterization of Earth-like exoplanets around Sun-like stars for the first time. The quest for the optimal optical coronagraph designs has made rapid progress in recent years thanks to the Segmented Coronagraph Design and Analysis (SCDA) initiative led by the Exoplanet Exploration Program at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. As a result, several types of high-performance designs have emerged that make use of dual deformable mirrors to (1) correct for optical aberrations and (2) suppress diffracted starlight from obstructions and discontinuities in the telescope pupil. However, the algorithms used to compute the optimal deformable mirror surface tend to be computationally intensive, prohibiting large scale design surveys. Here, we utilize the Fast Linearized Coronagraph Optimizer (FALCO), a tool that allows for rapid optimization of deformable mirror shapes, to explore trade-offs in coronagraph designs for obstructed and segmented space telescopes. We compare designs for representative shaped pupil Lyot and vortex coronagraphs, two of the most promising concepts for the LUVOIR space mission concept. We analyze the optical performance of each design, including their throughput and ability to passively suppress light from partially resolved stars in the presence of low-order aberrations. Our main result is that deformable mirror based apodization can sufficiently suppress diffraction from support struts and inter-segment gaps whose widths are on the order of âˆ¼0.1% of the primary mirror diameter to detect Earth-sized planets within a few tens of milliarcseconds from the star.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: One of the main goals of the Large UV Optical Infrared Surveyor (LUVOIR) mission concept is to find and characterize a diverse sample of exoplanets through direct imaging and spectroscopy. 1 The coronagraph instrument requirements are selected to maximize the number of Earth-sized planets studied in the habitable zone of nearby solar type stars. 2,3 Not only will LUVOIR potentially detect tens of such objects, it will also yield hundreds of super-Earths, sub-Neptunes, and gas giants as well as images of circumstellar disks in scattered light. This will be made possible by a coronagraph instrument sensitive to planet-to-star flux ratios on the order of 10 âˆ’10 as close as tens of milliarcseconds from the star from the visible to the near-infrared. 4 Achieving a raw contrast of 10 âˆ’10 on a telescope with a segmented primary mirror requires coronagraph masks that are specially tailored to suppress, or "apodize," the complicated diffraction patterns from the gaps between mirror segments and potential obscurations due to an on-axis secondary mirror and its corresponding support structures. Apodization of the stellar point spread function (PSF) is either achieved by changing the pupil shape, 5 introducing a pupil mask that imparts a grayscale pattern, 6 or shaping the beam with phase induced amplitude apodization using fixed beam shaping optics 7 or active deformable mirrors (DMs), 8,9 or a combination of any of the above. Several methods for the active compensation of aperture discontinuities (ACAD) with DMs â€ Send correspondence to gruane@caltech.edu arXiv: 1807 have been introduced, including computing geometric solutions 8 and closed-loop wavefront control methods 10,11 that make use of electric field conjugation, 12 stroke minimization, 13 and expectation-maximization 14 algorithms.

The Fast Linearized Coronagraph Optimizer (FALCO) 15 is a new open-source software package that calculates the DM surface shapes that minimimize the amount of starlight in a predetermined region of the image creating a so-called "dark hole." FALCO significantly reduces the amount of time needed for such calculations with respect to previous methods used by our team. 16 Here, we use FALCO to perform a coronagraph design study for potential LUVOIR telescope apertures with shaped pupil Lyot 17 and vortex coronagraphs. 18-20 In the following sections, we present five coronagraph designs for potential LUVOIR apertures and compare their performance in terms of raw contrast, throughput, and robustness to stellar size and low order aberrations. We also study the effect secondary mirror strut size and the width of the gaps between mirror segments.

div.head: TELESCOPES AND INSTRUMENT
div.p: Although the LUVOIR telescope design is still under development in preparation for the 2020 decadal survey, we analyze the performance of coronagraphs for the two potential architectures shown in Fig. 1: an on-axis, centrally obscured aperture (LUVOIR A) and an off-axis, unobscured aperture (LUVOIR B). The primary mirror of LUVOIR A is made up of 120 hexagonal segments with the central segment missing. The central obscuration has an circumscribed diameter that is 10% of the inscribed diameter of the outer edge. LUVOIR B, on the other hand, is made up of 55 segments and is otherwise unobscured. Figure 2 shows a schematic of the coronagraph instrument. We assume the coronagraph has two 64Ã—64-actuator deformable mirrors with 62 actuators across the circumscribed pupil diameter. DM1 is in the pupil plane while DM2 is at a distance of R 2 /(550Î») downstream, where R is the pupil radius and Î» is the wavelength. Each actuator is represented by the default influence function distributed with the PROPER * software package. 21,22 3. DESIGNS FOR LUVOIR A In this section, we present shaped pupil Lyot and vortex coronagraph designs for the LUVOIR A aperture (Fig. 1a). In each case, we utilize an apodizer optimized to suppress the diffraction from the central obscuration and then compute the DM shapes needed to achieve a raw contrast of < 10 âˆ’10 for the LUVOIR A aperture, including the struts and segment gaps.

div.head: Shaped pupil Lyot coronagraph
div.p: A shaped pupil Lyot coronagraph (SPLC) consists of a binary apodizer, an annular occulting mask in the intermediate focal plane, and annular Lyot stop that is undersized with respect to the re-imaged telescope pupil. 17 They are a type of apodized pupil Lyot coronagraph. 6, 23-27

div.head: 1-D radial designs
div.p: In Coker et al. (2018, these proceedings), 28 we perform a survey to find optimal SPLC designs for a one dimensional representation of LUVOIR A. That is, the optimization is performed for an annular aperture with R in /R out = 0.1, where R in and R out are the inner and outer radii, respectively. For each combination of focal plane mask and Lyot stop inner and outer radii, the optimization algorithm returns the apodizer that provides the highest throughput and a stellar PSF < 10 âˆ’10 within the image of the focal plane mask opening in the final image plane over a spectral bandwidth of âˆ†Î»/Î» = 0.1. div.head: DM-assisted apodization
div.p: We insert the rotationally symmetric SPLC described above into the pupil of LUVOIR A such that the inscribed diameter D 0 = 0.9D, where D is the full circumscribed diameter. The inner and outer radii of the focal plane mask correspond to 3.7 Î»/D and 29 Î»/D. We optimized the DM shapes using FALCO to create the smallest possible stellar irradiance within the image of the focal plane mask opening computed at seven evenly spaced wavelengths over a spectral bandwidth of âˆ†Î»/Î» = 0.1. This was repeated for several strut widths ranging from 0.01% to 1% of D. Figure 3 shows the resulting coronagraph design for a strut width of 0.5% of D. The beam at the re-imaged telescope pupil upstream of the coronagraph masks (Fig. 3d) is modified by the DMs (Fig. 3e,f) to create the field amplitude shown in Fig. 3g just prior to the apodizer (Fig. 3a). After passing through the focal plane mask, the re-imaged pupil has most of the starlight (Fig. 3h) diffracted outside of the Lyot stop (Fig. 3c), where it is blocked before reaching the final image plane (Fig. 3i).

div.head: Vortex coronagraph
div.p: A vortex coronagraph 18-20 performs a similar optical function as the SPLC, but with very different coronagraph masks. Here, we use an apodized vortex coronagraph with a grayscale apodizer [29][30][31][32][33] that suppresses the diffraction from the central obscuration. The focal plane mask has complex transmittance given by exp(ilÎ¸), where l is an even integer known as the charge and Î¸ is the azimuthal angle. We assume a charge six vortex phase mask (l = 6) in the focal plane and an annular Lyot stop to take advantage of its innate robustness to low order aberrations. 20

div.head: 1-D radial designs
div.p: The modal symmetry of the vortex phase mask allows us to represent vortex coronagraphs with one dimensional functions. Ring apodizers 29 and polynomial apodizers 30 can be derived analytically. The apodizers may also be numerically optimized. As in the case of an SPLC, assuming a finite image plane mask yields a binary apodizer. 34 Numerical solutions for grayscale apodizers are available for vortex masks with effectively infinite extent. [31][32][33] Again, we first optimize the coronagraph for the case of an annular aperture. div.head: DM-assisted apodization
div.p: As above, we start with the solution for the annular aperture and optimize the DM shapes to reduce diffraction from the struts and gaps between mirror segments in the LUVOIR A pupil. We matched the outer radius of the image plane dark hole to that of the SPLC case (29 Î»/D) and optimized for a spectral bandwidth of âˆ†Î»/Î» = 0.1 at seven discrete wavelengths. We also generated designs with âˆ†Î»/Î» = 0.2 at nine discrete wavelengths and a dark hole radius of 28 Î»/D. Each were repeated for several strut widths ranging from 0.01% to 1% of D. Figure 4 shows the apodized vortex coronagraph design for LUVOIR A with a strut width of 0.5% of D. The DMs (Fig. 4e,f) reshape the telescope pupil (Fig. 4d) to create the field amplitude shown in Fig. 4g just prior to the apodizer (Fig. 4a). After passing through the focal plane mask, some of the starlight (Fig. 4h) is diffracted outside of the Lyot stop (Fig. 4c), where it is blocked before reaching the final image plane (Fig. 4i). The signatures of the struts and gaps between mirror segmented are spatially high-pass filtered such that the starlight diffracts outside of 29 Î»/D.

div.head: DESIGNS FOR LUVOIR B
div.p: In this section, we present shaped pupil Lyot and vortex coronagraph designs for the LUVOIR B aperture (Fig. 1b). In each case, we compute the DM shapes needed to achieve a raw contrast of < 10 âˆ’10 by suppressing the diffraction from the gaps between the mirror segments.

div.head: Shaped pupil Lyot coronagraph
div.p: A shaped pupil Lyot coronagraph (SPLC) also needs a multi-ring binary apodizer to minimize diffraction from a circular aperture. Therefore, we first optimize the apodizer for a simple circular pupil, then compute the DM shapes afterward needed to create a dark hole with the segmented pupil.

div.head: 1-D radial designs
div.p: As in the case of LUVOIR A, we performed a design survey to find one dimensional SPLC designs by finding the apodizer that provides the highest throughput and a stellar PSF < 10 âˆ’10 within the image of the focal plane mask opening in the final image plane over a spectral bandwidth of âˆ†Î»/Î» = 0.1 and âˆ†Î»/Î» = 0.2 as a function of focal plane mask and Lyot stop inner and outer radii. The best SPLC (see Fig. 5a

div.head: DM-assisted apodization
div.p: The diameter of the multi-ring binary apodizer is 84% of the circumscribed diameter of the LUVOIR B pupil. Therefore, the inner radius of the focal plane mask corresponds to 3 Î»/D. We optimized the DM shapes to minimize the stellar irradiance with dark hole outer radius of 28 Î»/D at nine discrete wavelengths over a spectral bandwidth of âˆ†Î»/Î» = 0.2. This was repeated for several gap widths ranging from 0.01% to 1% of D. Figure 5 shows the resulting coronagraph design for a gap width of 0.1% of D. The telescope pupil (Fig. 5d) is modified by the DMs (Fig. 5e,f) to create the apodized field amplitude shown in Fig. 5g. The actuator strokes near the outer edge of the pupil are larger than usual. This feature will be investigated in future work. After the focal plane mask most of the starlight (Fig. 5h) diffracted outside of the Lyot stop (Fig. 5c), where it is blocked before reaching the final image plane (Fig. 5i). Unlike the SPLC for LUVOIR A, the focal plane mask and dark hole outer radius are not matched causing more leaked starlight outside of 28 Î»/D.

div.head: Vortex coronagraphs
div.p: Vortex coronagraphs are well suited for off-axis telescopes as demonstrated in the context of the Habitable Exoplanet Observatory (HabEx) mission concept development. 20 They differ from SPLC designs in that an apodizer is not required in the case of a circular, unobstructed pupil. However, defining a circular outer edge in the apodizer plane is beneficial. We present two varieties of vortex coronagraph designs that use grayscale-only and DM-only apodization.

div.head: Grayscale-only apodization
div.p: We computed the grayscale apodization solution 32 shown in Fig. 6a using auxiliary field optimization (AFO). 14 The outer radius of the apodizer (Fig. 6a) and Lyot stop (Fig. 6c) are 84% and 82% of the circumscribed diameter of the LUVOIR B pupil (Fig. 6d), respectively. Assuming the apodizer (Fig. 6a) and vortex mask ( Fig. 6b) are perfectly achromatic, the DM surfaces ( Fig. 6e-f) remain flat, the pupil is unchanged before the apodizer (Fig. 6d), and a very dark hole ( 10 âˆ’10 ) at the final image plane (Fig. 6i) is generated over an infinite spectral bandwidth out to a radius corresponding to 28 Î»/D. The true limit of spectral bandwidth will be set by the wavefront sensing and correction of optical aberrations.

div.head: DM-only apodization
div.p: We also present an alternate approach that uses the DMs to create the desired apodization pattern. In this case, we use a circular aperture at the apodizer position in Fig. 2 with diameter 84% of the circumscribed diameter of the LUVOIR B pupil (Fig. 7a). The focal plane mask (Fig. 7b) and Lyot stop (Fig. 7c) are the same as the previous case. The field at the re-imaged telescope pupil (Fig 7d) is modified by DMs (Fig 7e-f) to create an apodization pattern in the following pupil (Fig 7g). Visually the apodized pupil and the field at the Lyot stop (Fig 7h) appears similar to Fig. 6a. However, since the phase applied by the DMs is fundamentally chromatic (i.e. scales as 1/Î»), starlight leaks inside the dark hole in the final focal plane (Fig 7i) at both ends of the spectral bandwidth (âˆ†Î»/Î» = 0.2) creating "barbell" shaped speckles that generally increase in brightness toward the outer edge of the dark hole (28 Î»/D). The centers of the barbells are located at the harmonic spatial frequencies associated with the segmentation pattern.

div.head: PERFORMANCE COMPARISONS
div.p: In this section, we compare the performance of the five coronagraph designs presented above in terms of their raw contrast, throughput, and sensitivity to stellar size and low order aberrations.

div.head: EFC convergence
div.p: The FALCO software package 15 implements electric field conjugation (EFC) 12 to compute the DM shapes that minimize the stellar irradiance in the dark hole using a linearized response matrix, also known as the control Jacobian, between the DMs and the electric field in the final focal plane. At each iteration, the DM is deformed by a linear step depending on the value of a regularization parameter. For this work, we re-compute the Jacobian and empirically determine the regularization parameter that yields the best raw contrast at each step. Alternate recipes may be easily explored with FALCO in future work. For most coronagraph designs, we reach the minimum raw contrast in the dark hole within five iterations. Figure 8 shows the mean raw contrast in the control region as a function of iteration and strut or gap size for the DM-apodized coronagraph designs presented above. In each case, the minimum raw contrast reached depends on the strut or gap size.

For LUVOIR A (Fig 8a-c), a mean raw contrast of 10 âˆ’10 is achieved for both the DM-apodized vortex coronagraphs (DM-AVC) and shaped pupil Lyot coronagraphs (DM-SPLC) with a strut size of 0.1% of D. However, larger struts begin to limit the mean raw contrast to values greater than the typical goal of 10 âˆ’10 . The mean raw contrast of the AVC and SPLC are approximately the same for a spectral bandwidth of âˆ†Î»/Î» = 0.1 (10% BW), but the AVC raw contrast degrades by a factor of âˆ¼2Ã— when the spectral bandwidth increases to âˆ†Î»/Î» = 0.2 (20% BW). The same grayscale apodizer (Fig. 4) is used for both the 10% and 20% bandwidth cases because the apodizer optimization for vortex coronagraphs is inherently achromatic. 31 For LUVOIR B, on the other hand, the mean raw contrast (Fig 8d-f) doesn't reach 10 âˆ’10 if the gap size is greater than âˆ¼0.01% for an SPLC and âˆ¼0.03% for an AVC. However, unlike the case for the struts in the LUVOIR A aperture, most of the diffraction from the inter-segment gaps appears near the outer edge of the control region (>15 Î»/D from the star) and therefore has a smaller effect on the scientific yield. Thus, DMapodized coronagraphs can sufficiently suppress diffraction from gaps whose widths are on the order of âˆ¼0.

div.head: Throughput
div.p: The relative throughput of a coronagraph compares the amount of light within the core of the off-axis PSF to the same quantity with the coronagraph masks removed and DMs flattened. Thus, this metric accounts for light that is blocked by apodizers, focal plane masks, Lyot stops as well as distortion to the off-axis PSF caused by those masks and the DMs. We integrate the signal in the PSF core within a radius of 0.7 Î»/D. Figure 9 shows the relative throughput of each coronagraph at the central wavelength. Overall, vortex coronagraphs have higher throughput and smaller inner working angles compared to SPLCs. The dashed lines show a minor loss in PSF quality due to an increase in DM stroke when the gaps become larger. The performance gained from using a vortex coronagraph is much more significant on the off-axis LUVOIR B telescope. The DM-AVC yields the best throughput, but struggles to achieve a raw contrast better than 10 âˆ’10 with gap sizes >0.1% of D. For larger gaps sizes, it makes sense to switch to using a G-AVC to achieve better raw contrast. However, the throughput of a G-AVC is much more sensitive to the gap thickness, which also drives the telescope design to gaps on the order of âˆ¼0.1% of D to take advantage of the high throughput of vortex coronagraphs.

div.head: Sensitivity to stellar size
div.p: The exquisite angular resolution of the LUVOIR telescope (potentially 10 milliarcseconds in the visible regime) make the finite size of stars a non-negligible source of noise. Figure 10 shows the stellar irradiance for a star with diameter of 0.1 Î»/D (âˆ¼1 milliarcsecond) normalized to the peak of the PSF with the coronagraph masks removed and the DMs flat. In the case of LUVOIR A, the SPLC is much more robust to the size of the star than the AVC, which leaks âˆ¼100Ã— more starlight. However, in the case of LUVOIR B, the AVC designs are nearly as robust as the SPLC design. This is a known effect due to diffraction from the central obscuration. 35 The strut and gap sizes (solid vs. dashed lines) also influence the sensitivity to the size of the star, though not to the same extent as the central obscuration. The AVC is much more sensitivity to the stellar size on LUVOIR A (i.e. a centrally obscured telescope) than LUVOIR B (i.e. an off-axis telescope). The SPLC performs similarly in both cases. All of the coronagraph designs yield similar stellar irradiance levels on LUVOIR B, except the performance degradation as a function of gap size is more apparent for the DM-apodized solutions.

The difference in phase shift applied by the DM on the beam originating from different points on the star increases with the stroke. This effect is also referred to as beam walk. 36 Figure 11. The raw contrast is computed at the image plane coordinate corresponding to an angular separation at 6 Î»/D from the star. The LUVOIR A pupil has a strut width of 0.1% and the LUVOIR B pupil has a gap size of 0.01%. The strut and gaps sizes have a small influence on the sensitivity to low order aberrations.

div.head: Sensitivity to low order aberrations
div.p: Each telescope aperture and coronagraph design combination has a unique response to low order aberrations. Figure 11 shows the change in raw contrast caused by introducing a wavefront error described by a Zernike polynomial at the plane of DM1. The raw contrast is computed at the image plane coordinate corresponding to an angular separation at 6 Î»/D from the star. Both coronagraph types are generally more robust to low order aberrations on LUVOIR B than LUVOIR A. The SPLC designs are more robust than the AVC on LUVOIR A, but have similar sensitivity to coma and spherical aberrations. However, on LUVOIR B, the AVC is much more robust to certain aberrations than the SPLC, such as coma and spherical, but is very sensitive to trefoil as expected for a charge 6 vortex coronagraph. 20 Larger inner working angle SPLCs and higher charge AVCs (i.e. l â‰¥ 8) may be designed to be much more robust to low order aberrations than the examples shown here and thereby relax telescope and other instrumental stability requirements.

div.head: CONCLUSIONS
div.p: We have made use of the new FALCO software package to design coronagraphs for LUVOIR A and B and compare their performance. The DM-assisted apodization approach tends to yield higher throughput than conventional apodization with grayscale or binary amplitude masks, but struggles to suppress diffracted starlight when strut or gaps widths are too large (much greater than 0.1% of D). Diffraction from thicker struts and/or gaps may be suppressed with conventional apodizers with degraded throughput (e.g. the G-AVC). AVCs have the advantage of providing higher throughput, larger bandwidth, and smaller effective inner working angles than SPLCs. However, SPLCs are generally more robust to stellar angular diameter and low order aberrations, especially on centrallyobscured telescopes. AVCs are very sensitive to stellar angular diameter with an centrally-obscured telescope (e.g. LUVOIR A), which would severely limit their utility in that scenario, but are as robust as SPLCs on off-axis telescopes (e.g. LUVOIR B). Overall, DM-AVCs on off-axis telescopes provide unrivaled all-around performance and the best scientific yield per unit telescope diameter and cost.
